You have to assume that third-party software works when you integrate with 
it. You have to assume that Java works. You have to assume that anyone you 
didn't write yourself works, otherwise you're testing someone else's code, 
and that is testing you shouldn't have to do.

But their stuff has bugs. I posted an example of a bug in IBM's EJB 
implementation on Wiki. They have an Enumeration that isn't really an 
Enumeration. I only found this out during unit tests. It happens.

So what can you do?

Fortunately, XP has a solution: quick releases and acceptance tests force 
you to integrate early and often so that you can expose these bugs in 
third-party software earlier. The good news is that, through unit testing, 
you can find these third-party bugs more easily. I would not be the least 
bit surprised if I were the first person ever to find this bug in IBM's EJB 
implementation. After all, who would bother calling "nextElement()" when 
"hasMoreElements()" returns false? My acceptance test did, because I wanted 
to avoid subtle bugs, so I looked under every rock.

But at least I found the bug early in my integration with the library, 
reported it, and perhaps they'll fix it. What acceptance testing did was 
make the bug show up now, rather than six months from now at an Australian 
customer's site. That would be a hefty travel bill.

So for unit testing, you have to assume that libraries work, otherwise you 
can't truly unit test. But make sure you have the appropriate 
integration/acceptance tests; otherwise, you'll not find bugs in those 
libraries soon enough.
